DataElement.preferredDefinition: A type describing the neoplasm by morphology based on Paris classification.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.:The science of the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.  In pathology, the specific appearance of cells and tissues (normal and abnormal) under the light or electron microscope.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Morphology is the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.

Concepts.definition: The science of the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.  In pathology, the specific appearance of cells and tissues (normal and abnormal) under the light or electron microscope.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredName: Neoplasm by Morphology Paris Classification Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A classification system grouping neoplasms according to their cellular characteristics._A classification system for the endoscopic assessment of early and/or superficial neoplastic lesions of the gastrointestinal tract that was adapted from the Japanese Gastric Cancer Association (JGCA) macroscopic classification for gastric cancer in 2002 by an international consortium of endoscopists, surgeons, and pathologists._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A Paris Classification subtype of superficial neoplastic lesions at the surface of the gastrointestinal tract mucosa that is characterized by a sessile polypoid endoscopic morphology, and where lesion height does not exceed 2.5 mm.

Concepts.definition: A Paris Classification subtype of superficial neoplastic lesions at the surface of the gastrointestinal tract mucosa that is characterized by a sessile polypoid endoscopic morphology, and where lesion height does not exceed 2.5 mm.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A Paris Classification subtype of superficial neoplastic lesions at the surface of the gastrointestinal tract mucosa that is characterized by a pedunculated polypoid endoscopic morphology, and where lesion height does not exceed 2.5 mm.

Concepts.definition: A Paris Classification subtype of superficial neoplastic lesions at the surface of the gastrointestinal tract mucosa that is characterized by a pedunculated polypoid endoscopic morphology, and where lesion height does not exceed 2.5 mm.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A Paris Classification subtype of superficial neoplastic lesions at the surface of the gastrointestinal tract mucosa that is characterized by a completely flat endoscopic morphology.

Concepts.definition: A Paris Classification subtype of superficial neoplastic lesions at the surface of the gastrointestinal tract mucosa that is characterized by a completely flat endoscopic morphology.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A Paris Classification subtype of superficial neoplastic lesions at the surface of the gastrointestinal tract mucosa that is characterized by a superficially depressed endoscopic morphology.

Concepts.definition: A Paris Classification subtype of superficial neoplastic lesions at the surface of the gastrointestinal tract mucosa that is characterized by a superficially depressed endoscopic morphology.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned._The science of the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.  In pathology, the specific appearance of cells and tissues (normal and abnormal) under the light or electron microscope._Be specific about something; define clearly.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

The science of the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.  In pathology, the specific appearance of cells and tissues (normal and abnormal) under the light or electron microscope.
Be specific about something; define clearly.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A Paris Classification subtype of superficial neoplastic lesions at the surface of the gastrointestinal tract mucosa that is characterized by a flat and elevated endoscopic morphology, and where lesion height does not exceed 2.5 mm.

Concepts.definition: A Paris Classification subtype of superficial neoplastic lesions at the surface of the gastrointestinal tract mucosa that is characterized by a flat and elevated endoscopic morphology, and where lesion height does not exceed 2.5 mm.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Neoplasm by Morphology Paris Classification Type
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A classification system grouping neoplasms according to their cellular characteristics._A classification system for the endoscopic assessment of early and/or superficial neoplastic lesions of the gastrointestinal tract that was adapted from the Japanese Gastric Cancer Association (JGCA) macroscopic classification for gastric cancer in 2002 by an international consortium of endoscopists, surgeons, and pathologists._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: A classification system grouping neoplasms according to their cellular characteristics.

A classification system for the endoscopic assessment of early and/or superficial neoplastic lesions of the gastrointestinal tract that was adapted from the Japanese Gastric Cancer Association (JGCA) macroscopic classification for gastric cancer in 2002 by an international consortium of endoscopists, surgeons, and pathologists.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
